text: <@U06P64XGS|vudv> has joined the channel

Someone have a simple solution to this problem, I have a private project in github  and I am creating an application that depends of that project in github. It is possible to add a dependency of a github project without publish it on maven or jcenter?
what builds your project?
travis?
Android Studio + Gradle
okay you can just maven deploy to mavenLocal()
I think install does that by default
I would really recommend against it though
internally we use jenkins to build our android libraries and deploy them internally to artifactory

I would recommend using artifactory regardless as its caching features make it worth it alone (caches remote repositories making gradle run faster as presumably you are typically downloading locally with it)
artifactory is a mess to publish to
strongly disagree
I use the same scripts to publish to artifactory as I do to publish to sonatype
I would suggest that you do not use their plugin though
if you are referring to that being a mess, I agree
yeah, their plugin
are you using the ever popular gradle-mvn-push or whatever?
no I wrote my own plugin using uploadArchives
I need to do a lot more than what that plugin offers so it just made sense to make my own
well more than what that script does anyways.. but my plugin is based on effectively what chris setup there
the only issue I have had is that I still have no idea how to get javadocs to work right
and I blame google for fucking that shit up
yeah the javadocs is really messed up
Guys have any of you used a Mardown parser for Android?
I have checked out Markdownjs and Bypass(using this)
<http://uncodin.github.io/bypass/>
Hum, I was looking for a more easier solution… Like put the the source code in a folder a import/build from a gradle dependency
nope but I need to actually
was going to try integrating bypass via the ndk
<@U04U01U4H>: if you assembleRelease you can take the AAR and copy it to your application projects lib directory
just make sure you have the dependency { compile libs} nonsense in your application module
yes, but I dont want to upload the aar to the github
I was looking for was something that checkouts the code and build
:smiley:
you could use submodules in git to pull in your library into your application project
Just add it as a GIT sub module then.
I would be really careful with that though, its easy to mess up using submodules
True story.
true, I will check that. Thanks!
Not sure if we are all talking about the same thing here
<@U0546QERR>: Yup bypass seems like the best out there
I was able to integrate it with my app
Works fine
<@U07BWL7K2>: the mention of bypass isn’t related to what everyone else it talking about but that does look like a neat library
Just looking for a better library preferably in Java
I actually have some uses for that
It is pretty exhaustive, but using native code is always a bit tough to manage
our ToS is in html and loading it takes a good second even on fast devices
so this seems like a good work around to get well formatted text without the weight
I wish it was pure java though
Yup makes sense. I am surprised Google hasn't come up with a markdown parser yet
who says they havent =P
:simple_smile:
Put it out there
when I went to my interview with them the engineer I talked to was working on some crazy tools
so rest assured, if its a good idea they probably have or are working on it internally
But they do open source libraries if they see there's a potential for developers to use it. Now markdown is all over the place, right from SO to GH
well they do open source libraries when they feel its not competitive against themselves
I think an open source Java Markdown library can be used for development related apps
I would agree with markdown though it seems like it would be useful for everyone
and non competitive
And it's a beautiful language
Well until then, bypass should suffice

<@U0542GLTE>: the example Nick posted the other day pretty much outlines that they dont understand activity/fragment life cycles and they don’t understand how to use styles, and they dont understand when to use handlers
pretty amazing that they managed to get all of that in with just 5 lines of code =P
Where was  this?
in the Orlando Dev slack
What exactly did they achieve(or not) in 5 lines?
Still not sure.
in onResume they change the background color of the actionbar by posting a runnable to a handler
Wha!? Why?
<@U055GGAHS|ian.shaun.thomas> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/ian.shaun.thomas/F07D31HDY/Untitled.java|Untitled>

file.name: Untitled.java
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight:
onResume(..) {
	new Handler().post(new Runnable() {
		getActionBar().setBackground(getResources().getColor(@color/somecolor));
	});
}

text: obviously that’s not the real code but you get the idea
I’m assuming they want it to execute after it was drawn already?
well by the time onResume is called its already inflated
Exactly
yeah, but nobody told them that :smile:
right, failure to understand the life cycle
I would also point out they are not checking if the actionbar exists either
so its a potential NPE as well
pffft,  checking for possible NPE’s is for wimps
Unless ofcourse  you give a crap about backward compatibility
well its not just that
if you just use the actionbar you are assuming the style sets one
Certainly not just that
What's the feature you would love to have on a Twitter client?
plenty of api tokens

No,
scroll to bottom
So basically, I got the info where position 0 is the oldest message in history. n is the newest message
gotcha
linearlayoutmanager has a stackfrombottom method
You can definitely do it
that works but I can’t figure out how to keep the scrolling sane
I built mine super quickly and never optimized the views worth anything before they shut down
I was mostly working on the socket layers
right
maybe my problem is I need reverse set true as well and then I need to flip my data
yep that was it
so when you need to implement it..
<@U055GGAHS|ian.shaun.thomas> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/ian.shaun.thomas/F07DKE9FD/-.java|Untitled>

file.name: -.java
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight:
linearLayoutManager.setStackFromEnd(true);
        linearLayoutManager.setReverseLayout(true);

text: then just make sure you check the instance state to see if you should scroll to position 0 initially as the recycler defaults to position N at the top
seems that doesn’t fix rotation but that is probably easy enough to fix

: face punch :

Hey guys the experience with retrofit is very good, easy structure and very robust :wink: My new challenge is to create a rotine that performs a requests every minute to a service… Someone know the best pratice to do that?
you mean, how to set up a Service in android? i.e. threads that run in the background independent of the running app
^ that might be the answer to what you’re asking haha
Yes… I think is an intent service but I am not sure
i can say a service is likely what you want, as for best practices specifically using those i’m not sure
i’ve only set them up in tutorial apps

The objective is simple, when the app is active, I want to pull data from the web service to refresh the database with new data. But I want to make the request every minute and I dont care in wich view the user is
Service
Doesn’t have to be an intent service
just start a service from your main activity
<@U063EMGDQ>: what do you mean every minute and what do you mean by view
if you literally mean every minute no matter what, you are really going to piss off the user as the phone will never sleep
if you mean that they need to be seeing the app for this to be happening and if they leave the app it should stop happening, this is a more complex problem

more complex in the regard that saying ‘make a service’ is not really the answer, you need to have a lot more thought to it than that because it will require a system to make sure you are doing the right thing at the right time

text: Which is why you wouldn’t use START_STICKY and let it start and stop on its own in OnStart and OnStop
true but I’m betting this is a a different problem entirely
aka if we knew what you where really trying to do the answer is likely completely different
Ok I will be more specific
I have a map with different markers, and from time to time I have to update the location from them
But this doesnt have to be in real time
update the location from them?

you mean the markers move, the same set of markers or does that change too. Aka can I imagine this as you have people out in the field walking about and some people will go offline and others will come back online?
Yes exactly :wink:
okay, so what about the history of the objects, it seems like you dont care if the end users get the history just the current positions
Yes only the current location...
this sounds like an excellent use for this <https://developers.google.com/cloud-messaging/topic-messaging>
But the point is… I want to update the location and the data attached from each person like the state and other properties
as needed users can subscribe and unsubscribe, users will only be notified of actual changes, and only the users that need to know about particular changes will be notified
its worth noting I would also only send the changed data
Oh I already use this to perform push notifications
not the full set
Hmm do you mean instead of performing a push notification I can update the data changed for subscribers and update the UI?
yes, the topics dont dictate what data you send so its just up to you to handle it. So if you already have users in topics, just stream the data changes to it
Web Services —> GCM -> Message(new data coming) —> App (subscribers) —> Update DB —> Update UI
Somehow like this?
yeah
Ok, thanks for the guidelines, I will give a try!
np
hope it goes smoothly
its definitely gonna be more scalable as 1 minute updates are pretty quick and you’ll end up hammering your servers if you get any scale
